content.title: Acute Pancreatitis
content.summary: Acute inflammation of the pancreas with autodigestion by pancreatic enzymes, most commonly caused by gallstones or alcohol, requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation and supportive care
key_points: Diagnosis requires 2 of 3 criteria: typical pain, lipase >3× ULN, imaging findings
Gallstones (40%) and alcohol (30%) account for 70% of cases ('I GET SMASHED' mnemonic for causes)
Aggressive IV fluid resuscitation (250-500 mL/hr crystalloid) in first 24h improves outcomes
Severity classification: Mild (no organ failure/complications), Moderate (transient OF <48h), Severe (persistent OF)
Early enteral nutrition preferred; NPO only if intolerant or severe ileus
Cholecystectomy during same admission for mild biliary pancreatitis to prevent recurrence
ERCP indicated for cholangitis or persistent biliary obstruction, not routine biliary pancreatitis
content.statement: Acute pancreatitis is an inflammatory condition of the pancreas diagnosed by characteristic abdominal pain, elevated lipase, and/or imaging findings, requiring aggressive early fluid resuscitation and severity-based management.

explanation.intuition: The pancreas produces powerful digestive enzymes normally kept inactive until reaching the duodenum. In pancreatitis, these enzymes activate prematurely within the pancreas, digesting pancreatic tissue and triggering severe inflammation that can spread systemically.
explanation.key_insight: The key to pancreatitis management is aggressive early fluid resuscitation (the pancreatic inflammation causes massive third-spacing), early enteral nutrition (maintains gut barrier function), and identifying the cause (gallstones need cholecystectomy; alcohol needs counseling).
explanation.technical_details: Pancreatitis pathophysiology involves premature activation of trypsinogen to trypsin within acinar cells, which then activates other digestive enzymes causing autodigestion. The systemic inflammatory response can progress to organ failure (ARDS, AKI, shock). The revised Atlanta classification stratifies severity by presence and duration of organ failure.

definitions_glossary.acute_pancreatitis: Acute inflammation of the pancreas with characteristic pain, enzyme elevation, and imaging findings
definitions_glossary.lipase: Pancreatic enzyme; >3× upper limit of normal is diagnostic in appropriate clinical context
definitions_glossary.revised_atlanta_classification: 2012 consensus criteria for diagnosing and classifying acute pancreatitis severity
definitions_glossary.interstitial_edematous_pancreatitis: Mild form with diffuse pancreatic inflammation without necrosis
definitions_glossary.necrotizing_pancreatitis: Severe form with pancreatic and/or peripancreatic tissue death
definitions_glossary.organ_failure: Respiratory (PaO2/FiO2 ≤300), renal (Cr ≥1.9), or cardiovascular (SBP <90 despite fluids)
definitions_glossary.pseudocyst: Fluid collection with defined wall occurring >4 weeks after pancreatitis
definitions_glossary.walled_off_necrosis: Encapsulated collection containing necrotic tissue; occurs >4 weeks after necrotizing pancreatitis
definitions_glossary.ranson_criteria: Prognostic scoring system using clinical and lab parameters at 0 and 48 hours
definitions_glossary.bisap_score: Bedside severity scoring: BUN, Impaired mental status, SIRS, Age, Pleural effusion
definitions_glossary.infected_necrosis: Bacterial infection of pancreatic necrosis; suspect with clinical deterioration after 7-10 days
definitions_glossary.ercp: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography; for bile duct stones with cholangitis

pathophysiology.mechanism: Premature intrapancreatic activation of digestive enzymes causing autodigestion, inflammation, and potential systemic inflammatory response

causes.mnemonic: I GET SMASHED: Idiopathic, Gallstones, Ethanol, Trauma, Steroids, Mumps/Malignancy, Autoimmune, Scorpion stings, Hyperlipidemia/Hypercalcemia/Hypothermia, ERCP, Drugs

local_complications: Acute necrotic collection (<4 weeks, necrosis present)

requires_2_of_3: Abdominal pain consistent with acute pancreatitis (epigastric, radiating to back)
Serum lipase (or amylase) ≥3× upper limit of normal
Characteristic findings on CT, MRI, or ultrasound

severity_classification.mild: No organ failure, no local or systemic complications
severity_classification.moderately_severe: Transient organ failure (<48h) and/or local complications without persistent organ failure

laboratory_workup: CBC, BMP, LFTs (ALT >3× ULN suggests biliary etiology)

imaging.ct_indications: Uncertain diagnosis, no improvement after 48-72h, or to assess complications
imaging.mrcp: If biliary etiology suspected but stones not seen on US

fluid_resuscitation.goal_directed: 250-500 mL/hr crystalloid (lactated Ringer's preferred) for first 12-24h
fluid_resuscitation.monitoring: Target UOP 0.5-1 mL/kg/hr, HR <120, HCT decrease of 5-10%
fluid_resuscitation.caution: Reduce rate if signs of fluid overload develop; reassess at 6-12h

nutrition.early_enteral: Start within 24-48h if tolerated; improves outcomes vs prolonged NPO
nutrition.route: Oral preferred if able; nasojejunal if oral not tolerated
nutrition.parenteral: Reserved for those who cannot tolerate enteral nutrition

treatment_options.pain_management: IV opioids (hydromorphone, fentanyl); avoid morphine concern is theoretical

biliary_pancreatitis.cholecystectomy: During same admission for mild pancreatitis to prevent recurrence
biliary_pancreatitis.ercp: Only if concurrent cholangitis or persistent biliary obstruction; NOT routine

necrotizing_pancreatitis.timing_of_drainage: Delay intervention until walled-off (>4 weeks) if possible

skos.definition: Acute inflammatory condition of the pancreas characterized by abdominal pain, elevated lipase, and imaging findings requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation and supportive care

learning_objectives: Apply revised Atlanta criteria to diagnose acute pancreatitis
Classify severity using organ failure and local complications
Identify biliary etiology and determine need for cholecystectomy/ERCP
Know when to escalate care to ICU
clinical_pearls: Lipase >3× ULN is more specific than amylase for pancreatitis diagnosis
ALT >3× ULN strongly suggests biliary etiology
Lactated Ringer's is preferred crystalloid (may reduce inflammatory response)
Early enteral nutrition within 24-48h improves outcomes - don't keep NPO
ERCP is NOT indicated for routine biliary pancreatitis - only for cholangitis or persistent obstruction
Perform cholecystectomy during same admission for mild biliary pancreatitis
Delay intervention for pancreatic necrosis until walled-off (>4 weeks) if patient is stable
Triglycerides >1000 mg/dL can cause pancreatitis - check levels

common_questions: Epigastric pain radiating to back with lipase 2000 - diagnosis and initial management?
When is ERCP indicated in biliary pancreatitis?
Biliary pancreatitis recovering - when to do cholecystectomy?

citations.reference: Banks PA, et al. Classification of acute pancreatitis—2012: revision of the Atlanta classification. Gut 2013;62:102-111

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on revised Atlanta classification and ACG guidelines

clinical_pearls: ERCP only for cholangitis or persistent obstruction
Same-admission cholecystectomy for mild biliary pancreatitis
